nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: The campus food bank operates from a converted store room near the mosque. Inside, shelves are stacked with donated groceries, and students sort items into boxes.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: Kak Sarah, the food bank coordinator.  She's been running this for 3 years, entirely volunteer-based.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: A senior student labeling boxes. His shirt says 'USM Volunteer Corps'.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: Shelves filled with rice, instant noodles, canned food, and basic necessities. Everything is organized by expiry date.

nodes.speaker: Kak Sarah
nodes.text: Assalamualaikum!  You must be the new volunteers from Prof Riza's class. Welcome to Pantri Siswa USM!

nodes.speaker: Kak Sarah
nodes.text: We collect surplus food from Dewan Makan and donations, then distribute to students yang memerlukan. Every week, we help around 50 students.

nodes.speaker: Kak Sarah
nodes.text: Today we're packing care packages.  Rice, milo, instant noodles, eggs — the basics. Can you help sort and pack?  It's simple but meaningful work.

choices.text: Of course, Kak.  Show me what to do.
I'll try lah, but I'm not sure how much help I can be.
Actually I thought I'd just observe first. Not ready to commit yet.

nodes.speaker: Kak Sarah
nodes.text: Alhamdulillah!  That's the spirit. Every pair of hands makes a difference. Come, I show you the system.

nodes.speaker: Kak Sarah
nodes.text: Don't worry, everyone starts somewhere. Just follow Hafiz there, he'll guide you. You'll get the hang of it quickly.

nodes.speaker: Kak Sarah
nodes.text: Hmm, okay. You can watch first lah. But honestly, the best way to understand is to just try.  No pressure though.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: For the next hour, you help sort donations, check expiry dates, and pack care packages. The work is simple but strangely fulfilling.

nodes.speaker: Hafiz
nodes.text: Not bad for first time!  You know, I started just like you.  Came once to fill my co-curricular hours. Now I'm here every week.

choices.text: What made you keep coming back?
How many hours you get for this?

nodes.speaker: Hafiz
nodes.text: I met a student once who said this was his only proper meal that week. Changed everything for me. Suddenly it wasn't about hours anymore.

nodes.speaker: Hafiz
nodes.text: Haha, I knew you'd ask. 2 hours per session.  But honestly ah, after a while you stop counting. The experience is worth more.

nodes.speaker: system
nodes.text: Objective completed:  Experience hands-on volunteering at the campus food bank. (SDG 2: Zero Hunger)

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: Outside the Student Union building, a small SDG awareness booth has been set up.  Colorful banners flutter in the breeze, and students mill about curiously.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: April from the Environmental Club.  She's been organizing campus sustainability events since Year 1.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: Matthew, an international student from Indonesia.  He's helping distribute eco-friendly tote bags.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: A group of students learning how to make enzyme cleaner from fruit peels.  Practical sustainability in action.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: A brave squirrel eyeing the free snacks at the booth. Even wildlife is interested in sustainability events.

nodes.speaker: April
nodes.text: Hey there! We're from Kelab Alam Sekitar. Today we're teaching simple sustainable practices — making enzyme cleaner, proper recycling, reducing food waste.  Want to join?

choices.text: Sure! I just came from the food bank, so I'm already in the mood.
Interesting, but I need to rush for class. Maybe next time?
Nah, I don't think this environmental stuff is for me.

nodes.speaker: April
nodes.text: Awesome! Here, try making this enzyme cleaner. Just orange peels, brown sugar, and water.  After 3 months, you can use it to clean anything!

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You spend 20 minutes learning about enzyme cleaners, proper waste separation, and how small daily choices impact the environment.

nodes.speaker: April
nodes.text: No problem!  Take this pamphlet. We're here every Wednesday.  And follow our Insta @usm_alamhijau for tips!

nodes.speaker: April
nodes.text: That's okay!  But you know, environmental issues affect everyone. Maybe just take a look? No commitment needed.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.text: Hey!  Thanks for stopping by. You know, back in Jakarta the pollution is really bad. Coming here made me appreciate clean air more.

choices.text: Yeah, we should protect what we have before it's gone.
Malaysia also got pollution what.  KL haze every year.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.text: Exactly! That's why I volunteer here. Every small action counts. Today we taught 30 students how to recycle properly. Imagine if they all do it!

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.text: True, but that's exactly why we need to act now right?  If we all just complain and do nothing, it'll only get worse.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.text: Thanks for being here!  Every person who learns spreads the knowledge. That's how change happens — one conversation at a time.

nodes.speaker: Student Group
nodes.text: We're learning to make enzyme cleaner!  Apparently you can clean drains with this. No more chemical cleaners!

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: The squirrel seems to approve of your sustainability journey. Or maybe it just wants the free kuih.

nodes.speaker: system
nodes.text: You've engaged with the campus sustainability community. (SDG 12: Responsible Consumption, SDG 13: Climate Action)

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: Near the bus stop, you notice someone sitting alone on a bench, looking at a care package from the food bank — the same one you helped pack earlier.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: A student you don't recognize.  She seems tired but relieved, holding the food package carefully.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: A campus cat lounging nearby.  USM is famous for its friendly cats.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: The cat meows at you.  Probably hoping for some of those biscuits in the care package.

nodes.speaker: Nurul
nodes.text: Oh!  Aren't you one of the volunteers from Pantri Siswa?  I saw you there earlier. I...  I just picked up my package.

nodes.speaker: Player
nodes.text: Yeah, that was my first time helping out. I didn't expect to...  I mean, are you okay?

nodes.speaker: Nurul
nodes.text: I'm okay now. My parents' kedai makan closed during COVID and never recovered.  Scholarship covers tuition but not much else. Sometimes by end of month...  it's hard.

nodes.speaker: Nurul
nodes.text: I was so malu at first to come. But Kak Sarah said 'there's no shame in needing help — one day you'll help others too.' That changed how I see it.

choices.text: I never realized students around me might be going through this.  Thank you for sharing.
Is there enough support?  Maybe the uni should do more.
Oh...  that's tough. Um, I should probably go.. .

nodes.speaker: Nurul
nodes.text: Most people don't know.  We look the same as everyone else kan? But seeing volunteers like you... it really means a lot.  You make us feel less alone.

nodes.speaker: Nurul
nodes.text: There are programs, but not everyone knows about them. That's why what you're doing — spreading awareness — is so important.  Keep going, okay?

nodes.speaker: Nurul
nodes.text: It's okay. I understand it's awkward. Just... remember that your help today really matters to people like me. Even if you don't see us.

nodes.speaker: Nurul
nodes.text: Anyway, I should head back to my room. Thanks for listening.  And thanks for volunteering today. It makes more difference than you know.

nodes.speaker: system
nodes.text: End of Chapter 2: Taking Action. You've seen how student initiatives directly impact lives.  The SDGs aren't just goals — they're about real people.
